Weather March 1805

bibl.author: Meriwether Lewis
William Clark
bibl.title: The Journals of the Lewis and Clark Expedition, Volume 3
August 25, 1804–April 6, 1805

geoDecl.note: No location. Daily weather report for the month of March 1805.

revisionDesc.change: 2016-010-06 Brian Pytlik Zillig Converted from P4 to P5.
2016-09-26 Karin DalzielAdded Geo Information from spreadsheet

row.cell:
State of the
River at ☉ rise
raise or
fallen Feet Inches

the snow has disappeared in many places the river par-
tially broken up— Mr. Larocque visits us—
a flock of ducks pased up the river this morning—

wind hard all day. visited by the Birn the great Chief of
the Big bellies
snow but slight disappeared to day

collected Some herbs pla[n]ts in order to send by the boat.
paticularly the root said to cure the bites of the mad dog
and rattlesnake.—
But little snow not enough to cover the ground

one of the men informed that the Menetares have plenty of
artichokes.—
some ducks seen to light in the river opposit the fort

a gang of swan return to day the ice in the river has given
way in many places and it is with some difficulty it can be
passed—

the ice gave way in the river about 3 P. M. and came down
in immense sheets very near distroying our perogues—
some gees pass today.

the first insect I have seen was a large black knat today—
the ice drifting in large quantities.—

it [river] raised 13 inch and fell 12. wind hard, ice abates
in quantity

a variety of insects make their appearance, as flies bugs
&c. the ice ceases to run supposed to have formed an
obstruction above.—

ice came down in great quantities the Mandans take Some
floating Buffaloe
ducks and Gees passing ice abates in quantity

div.note: This weather table follows Lewis's Weather Diary, with some discrepancies in Clark's table in Codex C being noted.
This temperature in Codex C is "26 a."
In Codex C this temperature is "31 a."
Clark has "28 a" in Codex C.
These remarks follow Lewis's in the Weather Diary, with exceptions noted. The dates follow Clark's in Codex C.
Clark has no remarks for this date.

In Clark's Codex C these remarks are placed, undated, after his remarks for March 19. The root is the purple coneflower which Clark mentioned in his regular entries as having collected on March 21, that date probably being correct.

Clark's undated version of this remark reads "The Indians raise a kind of artechokes which they Say is common in the praries. well tasted." The artichokes are Helianthus tuberosus L., Jerusalem artichoke. Barkley, 380. Lewis gives a more detailed description on April 9, 1805.
Clark has no remarks for this date.
